svcproc.title: OPERATION
svcproc.para: The voltage regulator limits the maximum voltage that the alternator will produce at the output battery terminal by controlling the magnetic field present in the rotor. The voltage produced allows enough current flow to satisfy the electrical loads placed on the system, up to a maximum current that the alternator is designed to provide.

The system voltage will be maintained at the regulator set point unless the electrical load demand exceeds the capability of the alternator at that voltage. If that occurs, the system voltage will reduce and current demand increases. If the demand is so great that the system voltage falls below battery voltage, the battery will discharge to supplement the current needed to meet the demands of the system.

A schematic of the alternator circuitry is shown in Figure 3. With the rotor turning, magnetic fields around the rotor induce voltages in the stator winding. The faster the rotor turns, the higher the induced voltage will be. The initial voltages will be generated by residual magnetism in the rotor.

As speed and output increase, voltage available at the diode trio becomes sufficient to supply field current for normal operation. When the output voltage exceeds the battery voltage, the alternator begins to drive the system voltage.

When the system voltage is below the voltage regulator setting, the regulator turns on the field current through the rotor and allows the alternator to produce as much output as possible for the alternator speed (rpm), temperature, and system voltage. When the voltage setting is reached, the regulator turns the field current off. When the field current is turned off, the magnetic field in the rotor collapses and the output voltage begins to fall. The falling voltage causes the regulator to turn the field current back on and the magnetic field to rebuild. This switching action of the regulator continues rapidly, keeping the output and system voltage very close to the voltage setting.
